item.title: Binding and sequestration of poison frog alkaloids by a plasma globulin
item.description: Abstract Alkaloids are important bioactive molecules throughout the natural world, and in many animals, they serve as a source of chemical defense against predation. Dendrobatid poison frogs bioaccumulate alkaloids from their diet to make themselves toxic or unpalatable to predators. Despite the proposed roles of plasma proteins as mediators of alkaloid trafficking and bioavailability, the responsible proteins have not been identified. We use chemical approaches to show that a ~50 kDa plasma protein is the principal alkaloid binding molecule in blood from poison frogs.
